description: A large, sexually dimorphic cockatoo from Australia. Males are solid black with brilliant red panels in their tail. Females are black with yellow spots and have barred orange-yellow tail panels.
temperament: Intelligent, active, and can be very destructive with their powerful beaks. They are not typically cuddly birds and are less common in aviculture than other cockatoos.
loudness: Very Loud. They have a loud, drawn-out, and far-carrying call.
vocalization: Not known for their talking ability. Their vocalizations are their loud, natural calls.
dietaryNeeds: Specialized diet is required, as they primarily feed on the seeds of eucalyptus and other native Australian plants.
healthPointers: Can live up to 50 years. They are not common as pets and have very specific dietary and aviary needs that are difficult for the average person to meet.
housing: Requires a large, durable outdoor aviary. They are not suited for indoor cage life.
